PROGRAM PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  A  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  required  to  prepare  a  results-based  lending  (RBL) 
program to be financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The TA will conduct due 
 
diligence work, including assessments of the following government’s systems that are related to 
the  implementation  of  the  RBL  program:  (i)  the  soundness  of  the  government  investment 
program,  results  and  links  with  disbursements  under  the  RBL  program,  expenditures  and 
financing, and implementation arrangements; (ii) fiduciary and financial management systems; 
(iii)  safeguard  systems  (environmental);  (iv)  procurement  systems;  and  (v)  monitoring  and 
evaluation systems. As a result of the assessments, a program action plan will be developed, 
including strengthening of the government staff capacity. A program result framework and 
matrix  will  also  be  prepared  with  clear  result  indicators,  including  those  to  be  chosen  as 
disbursement-linked indicators (DLIs).

D.  Consulting Services 
 
4.  The TA will require 7.5 person-months (pm) of international and 20.0 pm of national 
consultant services from a total of 11 consultants, to be engaged individually. ADB will engage 
the consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on Use of Consultants (2013, as amended 
from time to time). Lump-sum payments and/or output-based contracts will be considered for 
consulting services under the TA when appropriate. 
 
5.  The outline terms of reference for the consultants are described below in paras. 6 to 13. 
 
6.  Sector and subsector analysis. One international consultant (also for the technical 
aspects) and one national disaster management consultants will be engaged to review the 
available analysis and assessment on the disaster risk management, particularly on seismic risk 
management. The consultants will conduct additional analysis and assessment, as necessary, 
on the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats of the institutional arrangements,

including  the  government  policies,  strategies,  legislations,  and  plans,  on  seismic  risk 
management.  The  consultants  will  identify  the  potential  risks  for  the  program  design  and 
implementation and recommended corrective measures and actions for inclusion in the program 
action plan with clear results and monitoring mechanisms. 
 
7.  Technical aspects. One international consultant (also for the sector and subsector 
analysis) and one national disaster management consultant will be engaged to assess the 
government’s seismic safety investment program, including technical and economic soundness 
of the program (adequacy and economic efficiency), results and links with disbursements under 
the RBL program, expenditures and financing, and implementation arrangements. Necessary 
measures and actions to be taken to strengthen the government investment program will be 
identified for inclusion in the program action plan with clear results and monitoring mechanisms. 
 
8.  Economic  analysis.  The  consultants,  during  the  assessment  of  the  government’s 
seismic safety investment program, will assess the cost-efficiency of the program, including 
economic  rationale;  appropriateness  of  the  building  codes  and  standards;  demands  and 
prioritization  criteria;  adequacy  and  cost  efficiency  of  selected  technical  solutions;  and 
complementary measures to maximize investment impact, including the maintenance of the 
renovated school buildings. 
 
9.  Fiduciary systems assessment. One international financial management consultant, 
one national financial management consultant, and one national procurement consultant will be 
engaged  to  assess  the  program’s  fiduciary  systems’  ability  to  manage  fiduciary  risks  and 
provide reasonable assurance for the appropriate use of program funds. The overall output will 
be a fiduciary systems assessment and a procurement system assessment, which assess 
financial management, procurement and corruption risks and recommend mitigating measures, 
including capacity-development activities for inclusion in the program action plan with clear 
results and monitoring mechanisms.  
 
10.  Safeguards assessment (Environment). One national environment consultant will be 
engaged  to  assess  the  program  environment  safeguard  system  in  accordance  with  RBL 
guidance and develop action plans to address the gaps and recommend measures for using the 
national environmental regulations in accordance with the principles of ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement (2009). This will be based on the Armenia country assessment of environmental 
safeguard capacity study, which has recently been endorsed by Ministry of Environment and 
Natural Resources. The safeguard management system will consist of a screening checklist for 
potential  environmental  impacts  which  may  affect  the  program  design  and  recommended 
necessary measures and actions for mitigation, with clear results and monitoring mechanisms.  
 
11.  Monitoring  and  evaluation.  One  international  and  one  national  monitoring  and 
evaluation consultants will be engaged to assess the government monitoring and evaluation 
systems and identify gap that may affect the program implementation and results monitoring 
and evaluation. Based on the integrated risk assessment, the program action plan and the gap 
identified, the consultants will develop a monitoring and evaluation system for the program. 
 
12.  Social, poverty, and gender analyses. One national social and gender development 
consultant will be engaged to prepare poverty and social analysis using participatory methods in 
accordance with ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis – A Working Document 
(2012) and the operations manual on Incorporation of Social Dimensions into ADB Operations 
(OM Section C3) to assess the type and significance of the project impacts on the poor, women 
and any other vulnerable groups. The consultant will review ADB tip sheet on gender and

disaster risk management (2014) and existing guidelines or work done in Armenia on gender 
and  earthquake.  The  consultant  will  support  the  consultants  doing  the  assessment  of  the 
government’s  seismic  safety  investment  program,  by  analyzing  from  a  social  and  gender 
perspective  how  the  government  program  differentially  affects  female,  male,  and  disabled 
students, or other groups of students. The consultant will recommend the measures and actions 
for engaging and empowering the civil society organizations, women, and disadvantaged group 
during the program implementation to maximize the project impact, which will be included in the 
program action plan with clear results and monitoring mechanisms. 
 
13.  Integrated risk assessment for the program. All consultants engaged under the TA 
will assist the project team in reviewing and consolidating the risks identified and measures and 
actions  recommended  by  the  assessments  described  in  paras.  6-12  and  develop  a  risk 
mitigation plan with clear results and monitoring mechanisms.  
 
14.  In  addition,  a  contract  management  coordinator  will  be  engaged  to  manage  and 
coordinate the administrative and contractual matters under the TA. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The Ministry of International Economic Integration and Reforms will be the executing 
agency for the TA, which will coordinate among the relevant government agencies for the 
program  design  and  preparation.  The  government  will  provide  qualified  counterpart  staff, 
necessary logistics, and data and documents. Disbursements under the TA will be done in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended 
from time to time).
